column1: Edina ( (listen) ee-DY-nə) is a city in Hennepin County
column2: Minnesota
column3: United States. Edina began as a small farming and milling community in the 1860s. The population was 47

column1: Edina began as part of Richfield Township
column2: Minnesota. By the 1870s
column3: 17 families
column4: most of them immigrating as a result of the Great Famine of Ireland
column5: had come to Minnesota and claimed land in the southwest section of what was then Richfield Township. They were followed by settlers from New England and Germany
column6: who claimed additional land near Minnehaha Creek. The Baird and Grimes neighborhoods (which are both listed on the National Register of Historic Places) and the Country Club District (then known as Waterville Mills) in the northeast part of Edina were among the first areas to be established. The area then known as the Cahill Settlement
column7: at West 70th Street and Cahill Road
column8: was also an early community center and the home of Cahill School.In 1888
column9: the residents of the township held a meeting to consider founding a new village
column10: thus separating themselves from Richfield Township. The idea was favorably accepted by those within the community and a committee was established to oversee the transition.

column1: After the decision was made to form a new village
column2: a debate ensued regarding the naming of the new village.  Several town meetings were held in the Minnehaha Grange Hall
column3: during which the names Hennepin Park
column4: Westfield and Edina were suggested.  Minutes taken by Henry F. Brown
column5: a farmer and future owner (1889) of the Edina Mill

column1: A long debate ensued with regard to the name by which the corporation shall be called. A motion was made and passed to reconsider the vote taken at the previous meeting of the name of the proposed village
column2: Westfield.  Another motion was then made by Andrew Craik to call the proposed village Edina (upon moving to the township in 1869 from Edinburgh
column3: he bought and renamed the mill to the Edina Mill). Before the motion could be decided
column4: James A. Bull
column5: a member of the five person committee
column7: which was seconded by the majority.  However
column8: the chairman of the meeting called this motion out of order
column9: at which time disorder ensued with Baird
column11: Ryan and Bull declaring their intent to no longer serve as members of the committee if a gag law was to prevail. During this heated moment the meeting became somewhat boisterous until
column12: after a few minutes order was restored.  Seeing that no more work could be done at this time
column13: a final motion was made and passed to reschedule the meeting to a future date.

column2: the name Edina was finally chosen with a vote of 47 for and 42 against.There has been a prevailing myth about the decision to name the new village Edina
column3: which states that two opposing communities—the Irish Cahill community and the Scottish Mill community—fought about whether to give the community an Irish name (Killarney Lakes) or a Scottish name (Edina).  The 1860 census
column4: however
column5: indicates that there were no Scottish people in Edina in 1860
column6: and only a couple were present at the time of Edina's founding (1888).

column1: The first suburban development in Edina occurred during the early 1900s in Morningside
column2: a neighborhood in the northeastern part of the village.  As Morningside grew
column3: conflict arose between its residents who wanted more city services
column4: and the residents of the rest of the village who wanted to maintain Edina's rural character.  As a result of that conflict
column5: Morningside seceded from Edina in 1920 and became a separate village. In 1966
column7: the Village of Morningside once again became part of Edina.

column1: Edina was not the first settlement in its location.  According to historian Deborah Morse-Kahn
column2: the Quaker village that existed where Edina would be built included African American families of Civil  War veterans and freed slaves "became very involved in community life—especially as farmland owners
column3: civic and cultural leaders." At the November 1898 general election
column4: J. Frank Wheaton
column6: was elected to the Minnesota House of Representatives representing District 42
column7: which included all of Edina.  Wheaton beat his white Democratic opponent in every Minneapolis city ward and in every village within the legislative district
column9: even though the legislative district had only approximately 100 African American residents out of a total of 40

column1: In the early 20th century suburban development brought discriminatory policies that led to nearly all of the African Americans who had been living in Edina to move away.
James W. Loewen described the suburb as a sundown town. Researchers point in particular to Samuel Thorpe's development of the Country Club Historic District
column2: which used deed restrictions as means to exclude non-whites
column3: stating explicitly that: No lot shall ever be sold
column4: conveyed
column6: or rented to any person other than one of the white or Caucasian race
column7: nor shall any lot ever be used or occupied by any person other than one of the white or Caucasian race
column8: except such as may be serving as domestics for the owner or tenant of said lot
column9: while said owner or tenant is residing thereon. Other developments
column10: like that built by N. P. Dodge Corporation just a mile away
column11: followed suit in attempting to protect land values through racial policies. Though the Supreme Court ruled these kinds of discriminatory housing clauses unenforceable in its Shelley v. Kraemer decision of 1948
column12: reports of discrimination persisted through the 1950s and 1960s. According to the Edina Historical Society's story about the first black family in Morningside (then a separate village) in 1960
column13: attempts to keep them out included tactics like trying "to get [their] lot condemned for drainage." In response
column14: then-mayor Ken Joyce wrote a note dismissing the drainage concern and challenging citizens "to live the Golden Rule". Shortly thereafter the village voted in favor of inclusion.Jewish residents were also affected by exclusionary deed covenants. In the 1960s
column15: some residents boasted that Edina had "Not one Negro and not one Jew."

column1: Many major highways run through or are close to Edina
column2: making it readily accessible to those within the metropolitan area. Minnesota State Highways 62 and 100 divide the City into four sections. U.S. Highway 169 and Minnesota State Highway 100 extend north and south. Interstate 494 and Minnesota State Highway 62 extend east and west.According to the United States Census Bureau

column1: Before streetcar service was abandoned in 1954
column2: the Twin City Rapid Transit Company's Lake Minnetonka Line went through Edina paralleling 44th Street on dedicated right-of-way. After streetcar service was abandoned
column3: the right-of-way was developed as single family housing.The Dan Patch Line and successor Minneapolis
column4: Northfield and Southern Railway operated interurban service through Edina until 1942. Although in poor condition and rated for speeds less than 35 mph the tracks are still used by freight trains. Under the Dan Patch Corridor proposal commuter trains would operate between Minneapolis and Northfield with a station in Edina
column5: requiring hundreds of millions of dollars of upgrades to the rail corridor. A feasibility study was conducted in 2000 and found that while ridership would be high there would be a significant cost to upgrade the corridor for commuter trains. Due to this and strong opposition from residents living near the rail line
column6: the proposal was put on hold until other commuter rail lines could be built. In 2002 a legislative gag order was placed on the project
column9: and county rail authorities from discussing
column11: and building commuter rail on the Dan Patch Line. In 2017 the Edina City Council conducted a study on the pros and cons of passenger rail on the Dan Patch Line. The conclusion was to not pursue passenger rail at this time (as of 2018).
